   - **Muscle tone**
   - **Response to treatment**

6. **Special Considerations:**
   - **Abnormal muscle contraction**
   - **Head/neck involvement**
   - **Tongue involvement**
   - **Medication history**

**Special Considerations:**
- Document Provider Impression as Dystonic Reaction (DYRX)
- For pediatric patients, use pediatric dosing per MCG 1309
- **CONTACT BASE** for all dystonic reactions
- Transport to appropriate facility

title: LA County EMS Protocol 1240: HAZMAT Exposure
content:
**Protocol 1240 - HAZMAT Exposure**

1. **Scene Safety:**
   - **Do not approach** until scene is safe
   - **Use appropriate PPE**
   - **Call HAZMAT team**
   - **Establish hot/warm/cold zones**

2. **Decontamination:**
   - **Remove contaminated clothing**
   - **Rinse with water**
   - **Do not spread contamination**
   - **CONTACT BASE**

3. **Assessment:**
   - **Vital signs**
   - **Neurological exam**
   - **Respiratory status**
   - **Skin assessment**

4. **Treatment:**
   - **High flow Oxygen 15 L/min**
   - **Normal Saline 1L IV**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

5. **Medications:**
   - **Atropine 0.5-2mg IV/IM** - For nerve agent exposure
   - **Pralidoxime 1g IV** - For organophosphate exposure
   - **Ondansetron 4mg ODT/IV/IM** - For nausea/vomiting

6. **Monitoring:**
   - **Continuous pulse oximetry**
   - **Frequent vital signs**
   - **Neurological status**
   - **Response to treatment**

**Special Considerations:**
- Document Provider Impression as HAZMAT Exposure (DCON)
- For pediatric patients, use pediatric dosing per MCG 1309
- **CONTACT BASE** for all HAZMAT exposures
- Transport to appropriate facility

title: LA County EMS Protocol 1241: Overdose / Poisoning / Ingestion
content:
**Protocol 1241 - Overdose / Poisoning / Ingestion**

1. **Immediate Assessment:**
   - Assess airway and initiate basic/advanced airway maneuvers prn (MCG 1302)
   - Administer Oxygen prn (MCG 1302)
   - Initiate cardiac monitoring (MCG 1308)
   - **Check blood glucose**

2. **For Opioid Overdose:**
   - **Naloxone 0.4-2mg IV/IM/IN**
   - **May repeat q2-3min prn**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Monitor for re-sedation**

3. **For Benzodiazepine Overdose:**
   - **Flumazenil 0.2mg IV**
   - **May repeat q1min prn**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Monitor for re-sedation**

4. **For Alcohol Intoxication:**
   - **Thiamine 100mg IV/IM**
   - **Folate 1mg IV**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Monitor for withdrawal**

5. **For Ingestion:**
   - **Do not induce vomiting**
   - **Activated charcoal** (if appropriate)
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

6. **Medications:**
   - **Naloxone 0.4-2mg IV/IM/IN** - For opioid overdose
   - **Flumazenil 0.2mg IV** - For benzodiazepine overdose
   - **Thiamine 100mg IV/IM** - For alcohol intoxication
   - **Ondansetron 4mg ODT/IV/IM** - For nausea/vomiting

**Special Considerations:**
- Document Provider Impression as Overdose/Poisoning/Ingestion (ODPO) or Alcohol Intoxication (ETOH)
- For pediatric patients, use pediatric dosing per MCG 1309
- **CONTACT BASE** for all overdoses
- Transport to appropriate facility

title: LA County EMS Protocol 1242: Crush Injury/Syndrome
content:
**Protocol 1242 - Crush Injury/Syndrome**

1. **Immediate Assessment:**
   - Assess airway and initiate basic/advanced airway maneuvers prn (MCG 1302)
   - Administer Oxygen prn (MCG 1302)
   - Initiate cardiac monitoring (MCG 1308)
   - **Control bleeding**

2. **For Crush Injury:**
   - **Remove crushing object** (if safe)
   - **Control bleeding**
   - **Immobilize affected area**
   - **CONTACT BASE**

3. **For Crush Syndrome:**
   - **Normal Saline 1L IV rapid infusion**
   - **Sodium Bicarbonate 1mEq/kg IV**
   - **Calcium Chloride 1g IV**
   - **CONTACT BASE**

4. **For Amputation:**
   - **Control bleeding**
   - **Save amputated part** (in cool, dry container)
   - **Do not freeze**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

5. **Medications:**
   - **Normal Saline 1L IV** - For fluid resuscitation
   - **Sodium Bicarbonate 1mEq/kg IV** - For acidosis
   - **Calcium Chloride 1g IV** - For hyperkalemia
   - **Morphine 2-5mg IV** - For pain management
   - **Fentanyl 50-100mcg IV** - Alternative to morphine

6. **Monitoring:**
   - **Continuous pulse oximetry**
   - **Frequent vital signs**
   - **Cardiac rhythm**
   - **Response to treatment**

**Special Considerations:**
- Document Provider Impression as Traumatic Injury (TRMA)
- For pediatric patients, use pediatric dosing per MCG 1309
- **CONTACT BASE** for all crush injuries
- Transport to appropriate facility

title: LA County EMS Protocol 1243: Traumatic Arrest
content:
**Protocol 1243 - Traumatic Arrest**

1. **Immediate Assessment:**
   - Assess airway and initiate basic/advanced airway maneuvers prn (MCG 1302)
   - Administer Oxygen prn (MCG 1302)
   - Initiate cardiac monitoring (MCG 1308)
   - **Check for signs of life**

2. **For Blunt Trauma:**
   - **Begin CPR** if no signs of life
   - **Apply defibrillator pads**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Consider DOA** (Ref. 814)

3. **For Penetrating Trauma:**
   - **Begin CPR** if no signs of life
   - **Apply defibrillator pads**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Consider DOA** (Ref. 814)

4. **For Resuscitative Thoracotomy:**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Consider if appropriate**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

5. **Medications:**
   - **Epinephrine 1mg (1:10,000) IV/IO** - Give every 3-5 minutes
   - **Amiodarone 300mg IV/IO** - For VF/VT
   - **Normal Saline 1L IV rapid infusion**

6. **Monitoring:**
   - **Continuous pulse oximetry**
   - **Frequent vital signs**
   - **Cardiac rhythm**
   - **Response to treatment**

**Special Considerations:**
- Document Provider Impression as Traumatic Arrest - Blunt (CABT) or Traumatic Arrest - Penetrating (CAPT)
- For pediatric patients, use pediatric dosing per MCG 1309
- **CONTACT BASE** for all traumatic arrests
- Transport to appropriate facility

title: LA County EMS Protocol 1244: Traumatic Injury
content:
**Protocol 1244 - Traumatic Injury**

1. **Immediate Assessment:**
   - Assess airway and initiate basic/advanced airway maneuvers prn (MCG 1302)
   - Administer Oxygen prn (MCG 1302)
   - Initiate cardiac monitoring (MCG 1308)
   - **Control bleeding**

2. **For Bleeding Control:**
   - **Direct pressure**
   - **Tourniquet** (if appropriate)
   - **Hemostatic agents**
   - **CONTACT BASE**

3. **For Shock:**
   - **Normal Saline 1L IV rapid infusion**
   - **Reassess after each 250mL**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

4. **For Fractures/Dislocations:**
   - **Immobilize** affected area
   - **Do not attempt reduction**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

5. **For Head Injury:**
   - **C-spine precautions**
   - **Monitor mental status**
   - **CONTACT BASE**
   - **Transport to appropriate facility**

6. **Medications:**
   - **Normal Saline 1L IV** - For fluid resuscitation
   - **Morphine 2-5mg IV** - For pain management
   - **Fentanyl 50-100mcg IV** - Alternative to morphine
   - **Ondansetron 4mg ODT/IV/IM** - For nausea/vomiting

**Special Considerations:**
- Document Provider Impression as Traumatic Injury (TRMA)
- For pediatric patients, use pediatric dosing per MCG 1309
- **CONTACT BASE** for all traumatic injuries
- Transport to appropriate facility

title: LA County EMS Policy 802: EMT Scope of Practice
content:
**Policy 802 - EMT Scope of Practice**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2024

**EMT SCOPE OF PRACTICE:**

**EMTs are authorized to perform:**
- Basic life support procedures
- Airway management (BLS)
- Oxygen administration
- Vital signs assessment
- Patient assessment
- Basic wound care
- Splinting and immobilization
- Patient positioning
- Basic medication administration (as authorized)
- CPR and AED use
- Patient transport
- Documentation

**EMTs are NOT authorized to perform:**
- Advanced airway procedures
- IV/IO access
- Medication administration (except as specifically authorized)
- Advanced cardiac life support
- Invasive procedures

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- EMTs must work within their scope of practice
- When in doubt, contact medical control
- Document all care provided
- Follow LA County EMS protocols

title: LA County EMS Policy 802.1: EMT Scope of Practice (Table Format)
content:
**Policy 802.1 - EMT Scope of Practice (Table Format)**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2024

**EMT SCOPE OF PRACTICE TABLE:**

| **Procedure** | **EMT Authorized** | **Notes** |
|---------------|-------------------|----------|
| Airway Management (BLS) | ✓ | OPA, NPA, BVM |
| Oxygen Administration | ✓ | All delivery methods |
| Vital Signs | ✓ | BP, HR, RR, Temp, O2 Sat |
| Patient Assessment | ✓ | Primary and secondary |
| Basic Wound Care | ✓ | Direct pressure, bandaging |
| Splinting | ✓ | All fracture types |
| Patient Positioning | ✓ | As appropriate |
| CPR/AED | ✓ | All age groups |
| Patient Transport | ✓ | BLS transport |
| Documentation | ✓ | ePCR completion |
| IV/IO Access | ✗ | Not authorized |
| Advanced Airway | ✗ | Not authorized |
| Medication Administration | ✗ | Except as authorized |
| ACLS Procedures | ✗ | Not authorized |

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- This table outlines EMT scope of practice
- When in doubt, contact medical control
- Follow LA County EMS protocols

title: LA County EMS Policy 803: Los Angeles County Paramedic Scope of Practice
content:
**Policy 803 - Los Angeles County Paramedic Scope of Practice**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2025

**PARAMEDIC SCOPE OF PRACTICE:**

**Paramedics are authorized to perform:**
- All EMT procedures
- Advanced airway management
- IV/IO access and medication administration
- Advanced cardiac life support
- 12-lead ECG interpretation
- Defibrillation and cardioversion
- Transcutaneous pacing
- Advanced medication administration
- Advanced patient assessment
- Medical control consultation
- Advanced procedures as authorized

**Advanced Procedures Include:**
- Endotracheal intubation
- Needle decompression
- IO placement
- Advanced medication administration
- Cardiac monitoring and interpretation
- Advanced airway management
- Invasive procedures (as authorized)

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Paramedics must work within their scope
- Medical control consultation required for certain procedures
- Follow LA County EMS protocols
- Document all care provided

title: LA County EMS Policy 803.1: Los Angeles County Paramedic Scope of Practice (Table Format)
content:
**Policy 803.1 - Los Angeles County Paramedic Scope of Practice (Table Format)**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2025

**PARAMEDIC SCOPE OF PRACTICE TABLE:**

| **Procedure** | **Paramedic Authorized** | **Notes** |
|---------------|-------------------------|----------|
| All EMT Procedures | ✓ | Full EMT scope |
| Advanced Airway | ✓ | ETI, SGA, Cricothyrotomy |
| IV/IO Access | ✓ | All sites and methods |
| Medication Administration | ✓ | All authorized medications |
| 12-lead ECG | ✓ | Interpretation and monitoring |
| Defibrillation | ✓ | Manual and AED |
| Cardioversion | ✓ | Synchronized and unsynchronized |
| Transcutaneous Pacing | ✓ | All age groups |
| Advanced Assessment | ✓ | Comprehensive evaluation |
| Medical Control | ✓ | Consultation and orders |
| Needle Decompression | ✓ | Tension pneumothorax |
| IO Placement | ✓ | All sites and methods |
| Advanced Procedures | ✓ | As authorized by protocol |

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- This table outlines paramedic scope of practice
- Medical control consultation required for certain procedures
- Follow LA County EMS protocols

title: LA County EMS Policy 804: Fireline Emergency Medical Technician – Paramedic (FEMP)
content:
**Policy 804 - Fireline Emergency Medical Technician – Paramedic (FEMP)**

**Last Updated:** 04/01/2021

**FEMP ROLE AND GUIDELINES:**

**FEMP Responsibilities:**
- Provide advanced life support in fireline operations
- Medical support for firefighting personnel
- Emergency medical care in hazardous environments
- Coordination with fire command structure
- Medical triage and treatment at fire scenes

**FEMP Scope:**
- Full paramedic scope of practice
- Specialized training for fireline operations
- Hazardous materials awareness
- Wildland fire medical support
- Urban fire medical support

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- FEMP personnel must maintain current paramedic certification
- Specialized training required for fireline operations
- Follow LA County EMS protocols
- Coordinate with fire command

title: LA County EMS Policy 805: California Poison Control System
content:
**Policy 805 - California Poison Control System**

**Last Updated:** 04/01/2024

**CALIFORNIA POISON CONTROL SYSTEM:**

**Contact Information:**
- **Phone:** 1-800-222-1222
- **Available:** 24/7/365
- **Coverage:** Statewide

**When to Contact:**
- Suspected poisoning or overdose
- Unknown substance exposure
- Medication errors
- Chemical exposures
- Plant or animal envenomation
- Drug interactions

**Information to Provide:**
- Patient age and weight
- Substance involved
- Amount ingested/exposed
- Time of exposure
- Current symptoms
- Patient condition

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Contact poison control for all suspected poisonings
- Do not induce vomiting unless directed
- Bring containers/labels to hospital
- Document all poison control recommendations

title: LA County EMS Policy 807: Medical Control During Hazardous Material Exposure
content:
**Policy 807 - Medical Control During Hazardous Material Exposure**

**Last Updated:** 04/01/2025

**HAZMAT MEDICAL CONTROL PROCEDURES:**

**Initial Response:**
- Assess scene safety
- Identify hazardous materials
- Establish safe zones
- Contact HazMat team
- Notify medical control

**Medical Control Contact:**
- **Immediate notification** required
- Provide substance information
- Report exposure details
- Follow medical control orders
- Document all communications

**Patient Care:**
- Decontamination as directed
- Symptomatic treatment
- Monitor for complications
- Transport to appropriate facility
- Follow decontamination protocols

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Never enter hot zone without proper protection
- Follow decontamination procedures
- Contact medical control immediately
- Document all exposures and treatments

title: LA County EMS Policy 807.1: Prehospital Hazmat Incident Flowchart
content:
**Policy 807.1 - Prehospital Hazmat Incident Flowchart**

**Last Updated:** 04/01/2025

**PREHOSPITAL HAZMAT INCIDENT FLOWCHART:**

**1. Scene Arrival:**
- Stop at safe distance
- Assess scene safety
- Identify hazards
- Establish command

**2. Scene Assessment:**
- Identify hazardous materials
- Determine safe zones
- Assess number of patients
- Contact HazMat team

**3. Medical Control:**
- **CONTACT BASE immediately**
- Report situation
- Request guidance
- Follow orders

**4. Patient Care:**
- Decontamination zone
- Medical treatment
- Symptomatic care
- Transport planning

**5. Documentation:**
- Complete incident report
- Document exposures
- Record treatments
- Follow-up requirements

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Follow flowchart steps exactly
- Safety is paramount
- Contact medical control
- Document everything

title: LA County EMS Policy 814: Determination/Pronouncement of Death in the Field
content:
**Policy 814 - Determination/Pronouncement of Death in the Field**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2025

**FIELD DETERMINATION/PRONOUNCEMENT OF DEATH:**

**Criteria for Field Death Determination:**
- **Obvious signs of death** (decapitation, rigor mortis, decomposition)
- **Incompatible with life** injuries
- **No signs of life** after assessment
- **No response to resuscitation** efforts

**Assessment Required:**
- Check for pulse (carotid, femoral)
- Check for breathing
- Check for responsiveness
- Assess for obvious death signs
- Consider environmental factors

**Documentation:**
- Complete death determination form
- Document time of determination
- Record circumstances
- Notify appropriate authorities
- Follow local protocols

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Only qualified personnel may determine death
- When in doubt, begin resuscitation
- Follow local medical control protocols
- Document all findings

title: LA County EMS Policy 815: Honoring Prehospital Do-Not-Resuscitate (DNR) Orders
content:
**Policy 815 - Honoring Prehospital Do-Not-Resuscitate (DNR) Orders**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2024

**PREHOSPITAL DNR ORDERS:**

**Valid DNR Forms:**
- **State of California EMS DNR Form**
- **Physician Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment (POLST)**
- **Valid advance directives**
- **Hospital DNR orders** (if applicable)

**Verification Steps:**
- **Check form validity**
- **Verify patient identity**
- **Confirm form is current**
- **Check for alterations**
- **Contact medical control** if unclear

**When to Honor DNR:**
- **Valid form present**
- **Patient identity confirmed**
- **Form is current**
- **No signs of foul play**
- **Medical control confirms**

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- When in doubt, begin resuscitation
- Contact medical control for guidance
- Document all DNR verification steps
- Follow LA County EMS protocols

title: LA County EMS Policy 815.1: State of California EMS Prehospital Do-Not-Resuscitate (DNR) Form
content:
**Policy 815.1 - State of California EMS Prehospital Do-Not-Resuscitate (DNR) Form**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2024

**CALIFORNIA EMS DNR FORM:**

**Form Requirements:**
- **Must be on official form**
- **Physician signature required**
- **Patient signature required**
- **Date must be current**
- **No alterations allowed**

**Verification Checklist:**
- ✓ **Official form format**
- ✓ **Patient name matches**
- ✓ **Physician signature present**
- ✓ **Patient signature present**
- ✓ **Date is current**
- ✓ **No alterations visible**
- ✓ **Form is legible**

**When Form is Valid:**
- All requirements met
- Patient identity confirmed
- Form is current
- No signs of tampering

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Verify all elements before honoring
- Contact medical control if unclear
- Document verification process
- Follow LA County EMS protocols

title: LA County EMS Policy 815.2: Physician Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment (POLST)
content:
**Policy 815.2 - Physician Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment (POLST)**

**Last Updated:** 07/01/2024

**POLST USE AND VERIFICATION:**

**POLST Form Elements:**
- **Section A:** Resuscitation preferences
- **Section B:** Medical interventions
- **Section C:** Artificially administered nutrition
- **Section D:** Physician signature**
- **Section E:** Patient/surrogate signature**

**Verification Steps:**
- **Check form completeness**
- **Verify patient identity**
- **Confirm physician signature**
- **Check date validity**
- **Review specific orders**

**POLST Orders to Follow:**
- **Full resuscitation** (if indicated)
- **Limited interventions** (if indicated)
- **Comfort measures only** (if indicated)
- **No CPR** (if indicated)

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- POLST is a medical order, not a request
- Follow specific orders on form
- Contact medical control if unclear
- Document all verification steps

title: LA County EMS Medication Contraindications
content:
**MEDICATION CONTRAINDICATIONS**

**MORPHINE SULFATE:**
- **Contraindications:** Respiratory depression, severe asthma, paralytic ileus, severe head injury, increased ICP
- **Precautions:** Elderly, hepatic/renal impairment, hypothyroidism, Addison's disease
- **Interactions:** CNS depressants, MAO inhibitors

**NALOXONE:**
- **Contraindications:** None in emergency setting
- **Precautions:** May cause withdrawal in opioid-dependent patients
- **Interactions:** None significant

**NITROGLYCERIN:**
- **Contraindications:** SBP <90mmHg, severe bradycardia, recent phosphodiesterase inhibitor use (Viagra, Cialis), right ventricular MI
- **Precautions:** Hypotension, severe anemia, increased ICP, aortic stenosis
- **Interactions:** Phosphodiesterase inhibitors, alcohol

**OLANZAPINE:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, severe CNS depression, coma
- **Precautions:** Elderly with dementia, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, seizures
- **Interactions:** CNS depressants, anticholinergics

**ONDANSETRON:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, prolonged QT interval
- **Precautions:** Cardiac disease, electrolyte abnormalities
- **Interactions:** QT-prolonging drugs

**OXYGEN:**
- **Contraindications:** None in emergency setting
- **Precautions:** COPD patients (avoid high concentrations), fire hazard
- **Interactions:** None

**PRALIDOXIME CHLORIDE (DuoDote™):**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity
- **Precautions:** Renal impairment, myasthenia gravis
- **Interactions:** None significant

**SODIUM BICARBONATE:**
- **Contraindications:** Metabolic alkalosis, hypocalcemia, hypokalemia
- **Precautions:** CHF, renal failure, hypernatremia
- **Interactions:** Calcium channel blockers, digoxin

**TRANEXAMIC ACID (TXA):**
- **Contraindications:** Active intravascular clotting, hypersensitivity
- **Precautions:** Renal impairment, history of thromboembolism
- **Interactions:** Anticoagulants, thrombolytics

**ADENOSINE:**
- **Contraindications:** Second- or third-degree AV block, sick sinus syndrome, known hypersensitivity
- **Precautions:** Asthma, COPD, heart transplant patients
- **Interactions:** Theophylline, caffeine

**ALBUTEROL:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity
- **Precautions:** Cardiovascular disease, diabetes, hyperthyroidism
- **Interactions:** Beta-blockers, diuretics

**AMIODARONE:**
- **Contraindications:** Cardiogenic shock, severe bradycardia, second- or third-degree AV block
- **Precautions:** Thyroid disease, pulmonary fibrosis, liver disease
- **Interactions:** Digoxin, warfarin, beta-blockers

**ASPIRIN:**
- **Contraindications:** Active bleeding, known hypersensitivity, severe liver disease
- **Precautions:** Peptic ulcer disease, bleeding disorders, asthma
- **Interactions:** Warfarin, NSAIDs, alcohol

**ATROPINE:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, narrow-angle glaucoma
- **Precautions:** Elderly, prostatic hypertrophy, cardiac disease
- **Interactions:** Anticholinergics, antihistamines

**CALCIUM CHLORIDE:**
- **Contraindications:** Hypercalcemia, ventricular fibrillation
- **Precautions:** Digitalis toxicity, renal failure
- **Interactions:** Digoxin, thiazide diuretics

**DEXTROSE:**
- **Contraindications:** None in emergency setting
- **Precautions:** Hyperglycemia, fluid overload
- **Interactions:** Insulin

**DIPHENHYDRAMINE:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, narrow-angle glaucoma
- **Precautions:** Elderly, prostatic hypertrophy, asthma
- **Interactions:** CNS depressants, anticholinergics

**EPINEPHRINE:**
- **Contraindications:** None in emergency setting
- **Precautions:** Cardiovascular disease, diabetes, hyperthyroidism
- **Interactions:** Beta-blockers, MAO inhibitors

**FENTANYL:**
- **Contraindications:** Respiratory depression, severe asthma, paralytic ileus
- **Precautions:** Elderly, hepatic/renal impairment, head injury
- **Interactions:** CNS depressants, MAO inhibitors

**GLUCAGON:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, pheochromocytoma
- **Precautions:** Insulinoma, adrenal insufficiency
- **Interactions:** None significant

**HYDROXOCOBALAMIN:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity
- **Precautions:** Renal impairment, pregnancy
- **Interactions:** None significant

**KETOROLAC:**
- **Contraindications:** Active bleeding, severe renal impairment, pregnancy
- **Precautions:** Peptic ulcer disease, bleeding disorders, asthma
- **Interactions:** Warfarin, aspirin, ACE inhibitors

**LIDOCAINE:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, severe heart block
- **Precautions:** Heart failure, liver disease, elderly
- **Interactions:** Beta-blockers, cimetidine

**MIDAZOLAM:**
- **Contraindications:** Known hypersensitivity, severe respiratory insufficiency
- **Precautions:** Elderly, COPD, sleep apnea
- **Interactions:** CNS depressants, grapefruit juice

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Always check for allergies before administration
- When in doubt, contact medical control
- Document all medications and patient responses
- Follow LA County EMS protocols

title: LA County EMS Policy 802: EMT Scope of Practice
content:
**Policy 802 - EMT Scope of Practice**

**EMT SCOPE OF PRACTICE:**
- **Basic Life Support (BLS) procedures**
- **Airway management** - Basic airway maneuvers, suctioning, BVM
- **Cardiac monitoring** - 3-lead ECG interpretation
- **Medication administration** - Limited to specific medications per protocol
- **Patient assessment** - Primary and secondary surveys
- **Trauma care** - Splinting, bandaging, spinal immobilization
- **Medical emergencies** - Diabetic, allergic reactions, overdose
- **Pediatric care** - Age-appropriate BLS interventions
- **Transport** - Safe patient transport and handoff

**AUTHORIZED MEDICATIONS:**
- **Oxygen** - Via various delivery methods
- **Aspirin** - 325mg PO for chest pain
- **Epinephrine** - 0.3mg IM for anaphylaxis
- **Naloxone** - 2mg IN/IM for opioid overdose
- **Oral glucose** - For hypoglycemia
- **Nitroglycerin** - 0.4mg SL for chest pain (if prescribed)
- **Albuterol** - Via nebulizer for respiratory distress

**PROCEDURES:**
- **Airway:** Head-tilt chin-lift, jaw-thrust, suctioning, BVM
- **Breathing:** Oxygen administration, bag-valve-mask ventilation
- **Circulation:** CPR, AED use, bleeding control
- **Disability:** Spinal immobilization, splinting
- **Exposure:** Patient assessment, vital signs

**LIMITATIONS:**
- **No IV access** - Cannot start IV lines
- **No advanced medications** - Limited to BLS medications
- **No advanced procedures** - No intubation, needle decompression
- **No cardiac drugs** - Cannot administer cardiac medications
- **No pain management** - Limited pain control options

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- EMT scope varies by state and local protocols
- Must work under medical direction
- Cannot exceed scope of practice
- Must maintain current certification
- Document all care provided

title: LA County EMS Policy 803: Paramedic Scope of Practice
content:
**Policy 803 - Paramedic Scope of Practice**

**PARAMEDIC SCOPE OF PRACTICE:**
- **Advanced Life Support (ALS) procedures**
- **Advanced airway management** - Intubation, surgical airway, CPAP
- **Cardiac monitoring** - 12-lead ECG, cardioversion, pacing
- **Medication administration** - Wide range of emergency medications
- **IV/IO access** - Peripheral and intraosseous access
- **Advanced procedures** - Needle decompression, chest tube insertion
- **Pain management** - Narcotic and non-narcotic analgesics
- **Cardiac care** - ACLS protocols, thrombolytics
- **Trauma care** - Advanced trauma life support
- **Pediatric care** - Pediatric advanced life support

**AUTHORIZED MEDICATIONS:**
- **Cardiac:** Adenosine, Amiodarone, Atropine, Epinephrine, Lidocaine
- **Respiratory:** Albuterol, Ipratropium, Epinephrine, Methylprednisolone
- **Pain:** Morphine, Fentanyl, Ketorolac, Acetaminophen
- **Sedation:** Midazolam, Lorazepam, Ketamine
- **Antiemetics:** Ondansetron, Promethazine
- **Diuretics:** Furosemide, Mannitol
- **Vasopressors:** Dopamine, Norepinephrine, Vasopressin
- **Antidotes:** Naloxone, Flumazenil, Dextrose, Glucagon

**PROCEDURES:**
- **Airway:** Endotracheal intubation, surgical cricothyrotomy, CPAP
- **Breathing:** Needle decompression, chest tube insertion
- **Circulation:** IV/IO access, blood pressure monitoring, fluid resuscitation
- **Cardiac:** Cardioversion, transcutaneous pacing, 12-lead ECG
- **Medication:** IV push, IV infusion, IM, IN, IO administration
- **Trauma:** Needle decompression, tourniquet application
- **Special:** IO placement, blood glucose testing

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Paramedics can perform all EMT skills plus advanced procedures
- Must work under medical direction
- Can exceed EMT scope of practice
- Must maintain current certification and continuing education
- Document all advanced care provided

title: LA County EMS Policy 814: Determination/Pronouncement of Death
content:
**Policy 814 - Determination/Pronouncement of Death**

**DEATH DETERMINATION CRITERIA:**
- **No pulse** - Absent carotid pulse for 30 seconds
- **No breathing** - No chest rise/fall for 30 seconds
- **No response** - No response to painful stimuli
- **Fixed pupils** - Non-reactive to light
- **No heart sounds** - Absent heart sounds for 30 seconds
- **No breath sounds** - Absent breath sounds for 30 seconds

**OBVIOUS DEATH CRITERIA:**
- **Decapitation** - Complete head separation
- **Incineration** - Severe burns with charring
- **Rigor mortis** - Stiffening of body
- **Livor mortis** - Blood pooling in dependent areas
- **Decomposition** - Visible signs of decay
- **Massive trauma** - Incompatible with life

**PROCEDURES:**
1. **Assess for signs of life** - Pulse, breathing, response
2. **Check for obvious death** - Rigor, livor, decomposition
3. **Document findings** - Time, location, circumstances
4. **Notify appropriate authorities** - Law enforcement, coroner
5. **Preserve scene** - Do not disturb evidence
6. **Complete documentation** - ePCR, incident report

**CONTRAINDICATIONS TO PRONOUNCEMENT:**
- **Hypothermia** - Core temp <90°F
- **Drowning** - Cold water submersion
- **Drug overdose** - Recent ingestion
- **Electrocution** - Recent electrical injury
- **Trauma** - Unless obviously fatal
- **Pediatric** - Special considerations for children

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Only physicians can pronounce death in most jurisdictions
- EMS can determine death but not pronounce
- Follow local protocols and legal requirements
- Document all findings thoroughly
- Notify family with sensitivity and compassion

title: LA County EMS Policy 815: Prehospital DNR Orders
content:
**Policy 815 - Prehospital DNR Orders**

**DNR VERIFICATION:**
- **Valid DNR form** - Must be current and properly signed
- **Physician signature** - Attending physician must sign
- **Patient identification** - Verify patient matches form
- **Date validation** - Form must be current
- **State compliance** - Follow state DNR requirements

**HONORING DNR:**
- **No CPR** - Do not initiate chest compressions
- **No defibrillation** - Do not use AED
- **No intubation** - Do not place advanced airway
- **No medications** - Do not administer cardiac drugs
- **Comfort care only** - Provide comfort measures
- **Family support** - Support family during process

**DNR FORMS:**
- **State DNR form** - Official state form
- **POLST form** - Physician Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment
- **Hospital DNR** - Hospital-issued DNR
- **Living will** - Advance directive document
- **Power of attorney** - Healthcare proxy decision

**PROCEDURES:**
1. **Verify DNR form** - Check validity and signatures
2. **Confirm patient identity** - Match patient to form
3. **Honor DNR orders** - Follow specific instructions
4. **Document care** - Record DNR compliance
5. **Notify family** - Inform of DNR status
6. **Contact medical control** - If questions arise

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- DNR only applies to cardiac arrest
- Can provide comfort care and pain management
- Must verify form before honoring
- Document all DNR-related care
- Follow local and state regulations

title: LA County EMS Policy 822: Child Abuse Reporting
content:
**Policy 822 - Child Abuse Reporting**

**MANDATED REPORTERS:**
- **All EMS personnel** - Required to report suspected abuse
- **Immediate reporting** - Must report within 24 hours
- **No investigation** - Report suspicions, not proof
- **Legal protection** - Protected from liability
- **Confidentiality** - Report details confidential

**SIGNS OF ABUSE:**
- **Physical injuries** - Bruises, burns, fractures
- **Behavioral changes** - Withdrawn, aggressive, fearful
- **Environmental** - Unsafe living conditions
- **Neglect** - Poor hygiene, malnutrition, medical neglect
- **Sexual abuse** - Inappropriate behavior, physical signs

**REPORTING PROCEDURES:**
1. **Document findings** - Detailed description of injuries
2. **Contact DCFS** - Department of Children and Family Services
3. **Complete form** - 11166PC form if required
4. **Notify supervisor** - Inform chain of command
5. **Preserve evidence** - Do not disturb scene
6. **Follow up** - Ensure report was received

**DOCUMENTATION:**
- **Detailed description** - Exact location and appearance of injuries
- **Patient statements** - What patient/family says
- **Environmental factors** - Living conditions, safety
- **Witnesses** - Names and contact information
- **Timeline** - When injuries occurred

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Report suspicions, not proof of abuse
- Better to over-report than under-report
- Document everything thoroughly
- Maintain professional demeanor
- Follow chain of command

title: LA County EMS Policy 834: Patient Refusal of Treatment
content:
**Policy 834 - Patient Refusal of Treatment**

**REFUSAL REQUIREMENTS:**
- **Mental capacity** - Patient must be alert and oriented
- **Informed consent** - Explain risks of refusal
- **Documentation** - Complete refusal form
- **Witness signature** - Third party witness
- **Base contact** - Contact medical control
- **Follow-up** - Provide alternative care options

**ASSESSMENT CRITERIA:**
- **Alert and oriented** - Person, place, time, event
- **Understanding** - Comprehends risks and consequences
- **Voluntary** - Not under duress or coercion
- **Competent** - Legal age and mental capacity
- **Informed** - Understands treatment options

**DOCUMENTATION:**
- **Refusal form** - Complete AMA form
- **Patient signature** - Must sign refusal
- **Witness signature** - Third party witness
- **Risk explanation** - Document risks discussed
- **Alternative care** - Options provided
- **Follow-up** - Instructions given

**PROCEDURES:**
1. **Assess capacity** - Ensure patient can make decision
2. **Explain risks** - Detail consequences of refusal
3. **Offer alternatives** - Other care options
4. **Complete form** - Fill out refusal documentation
5. **Obtain signatures** - Patient and witness
6. **Contact base** - Notify medical control
7. **Document care** - Record all interactions

**CRITICAL NOTES:**
- Patient has right to refuse treatment
- Must be mentally competent to refuse
- Document everything thoroughly
- Contact base for guidance
- Provide alternative care options
